div3.head: The Select Ball.
div3.p:
--As many ladies and gentlemen have desired to know whether the Ball next Tuesday night, at Monticello Hall, will certainly be select. I take occasion to say that the tickets have been placed in the hands of responsible and respectable gentlemen, who have pledged themselves to sell one to no man whom they cannot recommend as a gentleman, nor allow invitations to be sent to any ladies except under the same restrictions.
Emphatically no tickets sold at the door, and no person admitted without presenting a ticket.

div3.head: African Church.
div3.p:
--The large audiences of the ladies and gentlemen of Richmond who have attended the
Concerts
of
Mr. and the Misses Sloman,
Are respectfully informed that the following performances have been selected for
Monday, April 13th:
Lucrezia Borgia, Sonnambuls, Mendelsohn's Concerts in G Minor, Lucia de Lammermoor, Fra Dlavolo.
Vocal — Shakespeare, Romeo and Juliet, Tennyson's Come into the Garden, Maud Cavatina, Barber of Seville, Lno Lern, Frey Schulz by Miss Elizabeth and Anne Sloman. Shakespearean Extravaganza, Life and Death of King Richard the Third, The isseltos Bough, or The Loves of Lord Lovel, and Nancy Bell, Follow the Drum, and Betsey Baker, by Mr. Sloman.

div3.head: Fashionable Dancing Academy.
div3.p: --Prof Bingham begs to inform the ladies and gentlemen of Richmond that his Academy will be on Broad street, between 6th and 7th, Monticello Hall, after Tuesday, April 14th where he will be happy to receive a few more Ladies, Gentlemen, and Children as scholars.

P. S.--By particular request Mr. Bingham will prolong his session until the 1st of September, 1863.
Exhibition Ball for the children will take place about the 15th of June.

A Grand Ball
Will be given at the
South side Hall,
On Byrd street, between 9th and 10th,
By the Georgetown Quadrille Association, on
Monday Evening, April 13, 1863.
Tickets admitting a gentleman and ladies, $3.
Managers.
B E Franklin, J M Alfread.

Select Ball.--
given by
Prof J St Maur Bingham,
at his Academy, Monticello Hall, Broad,
between 6th and 7th streets, on
Tuesday Evening, April 14th, 1863.
Floor Managers.--Prof J St Maur Bingham, C N Smith, Esq.,--J M Wilks, Esq.
Smith's Band will be in attendance.
Price of admittance, (including refreshments) $10
Each gentleman is privileged to bring two ladies.
In order to ensure the respectability of the Ball, the tickets will be placed in the hands of the above Managers to sell, none others having the privilege to sell.

Gentlemen purchasing tickets, and wishing invitations for ladies, can procure them from the Managers.
Positively no ladies admitted without showing their invitation on "entrie. "
No tickets sold at the door.
Prof Bingham can be found at his present Academy, No. 65 Main street, where tickets can also be procured, between the hours of 10 and 12 o'clock A M.
An efficient guard will be in attendance.
Doors open at 8½ o'clock.

div3.head: Marylanders, attention.
div3.p:
--I want a few good men to complete my Company, now organizing for the 1st Maryland Battalion.
This is a desirable company, and these joining will there by find a good company without waiting long for an organization after enlisting.
Marylanders, come forward and let the old State be well represented in the great struggle for Southern liberty Good quarters, regions, clothing, and $10 bounty will be given each, volunteer.
div3.closer:
D M Snovell,
Capt and Recruiting Officer,
Bank street, 3d east of 10th; or 17th street, between Franklin and Main. ap 10--5t*

div3.head:
By Goddin & Apperson.
Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Commissioner's Sale of two valuable Lots on the East side of Union, between Grace and Franklin streets, and on the East side of Valley, between Richard and Baldwin streets.--As Commissioner, appointed by a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond, pronounced on the--March, 1863, in the case of Carrington against Carrington, &c, I shall in further execution thereof, proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 10th April, 1863, at 12 o'clock M, lot No. 26 in Adams's division, fronting 22 feet on the east side of Union street, running back 70 feet to an alley, (having thereon a frame building belonging to the tenant) now renting for $100 per annum.
Also, Lot letter N, fronting 44 feet on the east side of Valley, near to Baldwin street, running back 125 feet.

Terms.--Enough in each to defray the costs of the suit and expenses of sale; balance at 3,6, and 9 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, satisfactorily indorsed; or all each, at the option of the purchasers.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchasers.
div3.closer:
Geo W Randolph,
Commissioner. ap 13

div3.head: Very valuable Real estate on Virginia street, near to the Danville Depot, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 21st April, 1863, at 1 o'clock P M, that truly valuable lot located as above.
It fronts on the West side of Virginia street 62¼ feet, and runs back an average depth of about 93 feet. The central position of this lot, it being next to the Tobacco Exchange building, and its proximity to the Danville Railroad Depot, the principal tobacco warehouses, and four miles, makes it one amongst the most valuable lots that has been offered for sale during the war. It is bounded on the South by an alley seven feet wide, running through from Virginia to 13th street, thus giving the advantage of a corner lot.

Terms.--One third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.
The taxes for this year to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Valuable Ashland property for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--The subscriber will offer for sale, on the premises at auction, on Friday, April 17, 1863, at 11 o'clock A M, the very desirable house and lot on which he now resides, in the town of Ashland, Hanover county, sixteen miles by railroad from Richmond.
The house contains four commodious rooms, two on each floor, with a ball both above and below.
The lot, on which are a good kitchen and other cut buildings, contains about an acre and a half of land, suitable for gardening.
The location is an admirable one for a physician, whose professional services would be in demand, as none now resides in the town.--The purchaser, to whom immediate possession will be given, will be entitled to a free, ticket to and from the city for twenty years.
Also, at the same time and place, all the Household and Kitchen Furniture, one Cow and Calf, Hogs, etc. Terms--Cash.

div3.head: Desirable frame Tenement on the North of Main, between Monroe and Henry streets, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:

The Lot has a front of 2½ feet, and a depth of 153 feet to an alley.

Terms.--Cash or credit, at the option of the purchaser.
The taxes and insurance for this year to be paid by the purchase.

div3.head: A desirable residence for Sale.
div3.p:
--I will sell at public auction, at Chesterfield Court House, on Monday, the 13th April next — that being Court day — the tract of Land on which I recently resided containing 100 acres, lying six miles South of Chesterfield Court-House, twelve from Petersburg, and about twenty from Richmond.
Between 49 and 50 acres of this land have been recently cleared; the balance is in original oak and pine woods.

This is a newly settled place, and has all the necessary houses, which, together with the fencing, yard, garden, etc., are new and in good order.--The dwelling is a two-story building, with three rooms and passage.
There is, also enough seasoned timber in the yard to add another room, same size, which would make a large, convenient, and attractive building.
There are about thirty bushels of winter oats seeded on the land, which are looking well.

I will also sell at the same time and place, 86¼ acres of Land lying only a few hundred yards from the above tract, and on the same road.
About 20 acres of this Land have been cut down, but not enclosed; the balance is in oak and pine.
There are other lands adjoining these tracts which can be bought.
Mr. J N J Dunston will show this land to any person who may wish to see it.

div3.head: By James M, Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.
div3.p:
Beautiful Suburban residence, with 37 acres of valuable and highly improved Land attached, about one fourth of a mile from the town of Manchester — A most retired and lovely spot, located in a beautiful cedar grove, with laws in front, commanding a splendid view of the city of Richmond and surrounding country.
Taken altogether it is one of the most delightful and desirable situations, possessing more advantages than any place near this or any other city.
The improvements consist of a large and handsomely constructed and commodious brick residence, containing ten large and any rooms, closets, &c, beautifully arranged for comfort and luxury.
Attached are a kitchen, quarter, barn, stables, a fine and costly ice house, built of brick, a spring house and dairy, built of brick and stone, large and capacious.
A few steps from the house there is a large and bold spring, discharging gallons of most excellent water every hour, employing into a large ice pond, also conveyed through the dairy.
The yard is paved with brick and flagging.

We will sell, upon the premises, on Wednesday, the 22d inst., at 4½ o'clock P M, the above described farm, known as "Fonticello," the late residence of Fred Clarke, dec'd, adjoining the lands of Messrs. Samuel Hardgrove, and Holden Rhodes, dec'd, containing, as above, 37 acres, adapted to the growth of the choicest vegetables.
Persons desiring to secure a choice and rural home, with so many advantages, are particularly requested to examine the same before the day of sale.
Terms.--One-third cash, (or the whole, if preferred;) the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and secured by a deed of trust.
div3.closer:
Jas M Taylor & Son,
Auctioneers. ap 13

div4.head: Extensive Sale of valuable Real estate, Slaves, Horses, Mules, cattle, hope crop of Grain, Forage, Farming Implements, &c. At Auction.
div4.p: --By virtue of a deed executed by B. W. Green and wife, to the undersigned and orders as Trustees, dated 21st February, 1861, and recorded in Henrico County Court Office, and with the consent of the parties interested therein as the only acting Trustee, I will sell at public auction, in the order named below, upon the premises respectively, commencing on Monday, the 12th day of April, 1863, at 10 o'clock A M, (if fair; it not, then on the next fair day thereafter,) at the same hour, the following Real Estate conveyed by the said deed, to wit:

list.item:
1.
the estate formerly owned by Gen. Bernard Peyton, lying on James river and on the river road, about seven miles above Richmond, embracing the farms known as "Westham Cottage" and "Ambler's" containing about 1,230 acres, conspiring of about 370 acres of James river low grounds, 438 acres of open high land, and 225 acres of wood land.
The open land will be laid off into three tracts, with low grounds to each — say about 335 acres in each tract.
Upon one of the tracts there is a dwelling with excellent out buildings of every kind; and upon another tract there is a most extensive and valuable water power immediately on the canal, which is well worthy the attention of those wishing such property.
the wood land will be divided into three tracts of 75 acres each.
This is said to be the most heavily timbered land in this vicinity, and being within a few hundred yards of the canal is of great value.

2. the Farm just beyond the above adjoining the lands of Messrs. Higginbotham Wickham, and others, being the former seat of Col. Ambler, and more recently of Dr. Duval containing 150 acres, with about 150 acres in woods.
The improvements consist of a dwelling in a beautiful oakgrove, with a fine spring in the yard, good out-buildings of every kind, and an extensive and fine orchard.

3. the lands derived from Dr. Hopkins's estate, Mrs. Howle, Thomas Gordon, and others, containing in the aggregate 837 acres, lying on the three Chopped road and deep run turnpike, adjoining the lands of G G Exall, R a J Smith, E D Carter, Mrs. Green, and others.
This property will be laid off into four tracts, ranging in size from 132 to 265 acres, upon two of which are good dwellings, with the usual out-houses.
4. a small tract of land purchased from Thomas Ginnett, containing 15½ acres, adjoining the property of Mrs. Green, near the mill.

5. the tract of land on the river road, near the Forks, at the terminus of the plankroad, and adjoining Westham, containing about 175 acres, of which 75 acres are James river low grounds of excellent quality, the remainder being high land, with a portion thereof in woods.
This tract will be sold in five parcel, upon one of which there is a large quantity of the best brick clay, lying immediately on the canal.

6. the Farm known as "Glenburnie," on the plankroad, about four miles from the city, adjoining the lands of a L Ellett, Esq, and others, containing 180 acres, with an excellent dwelling and out-houses fine orchard, &c. This Farm will be divided into three tracts, which, being near the city and accessible by good roads, should attract persons wishing pretty country seats.

div4.p:
it will be seen from the foregoing descriptions that there will be sold twenty tracts, ranging in size from 15 to 350 acres, lying from four to nine miles from the city, and possessing almost every variety of situation and character, thus affording to purchasers a wide range of choice from which to make their selections.
These lands are for the most part in good condition; upon portions of them crops of wheat and winter eats have been seeded and are looking well, and immediate possession will be given so as to enable purchasers to put in the spring crops.

upon the day following, say on Tuesday, the 14th day of April, commencing at 10 o'clock a M, at the Peyton Farm, will be sold the following personal property, viz: 35 Slaves, consisting of men, woman, boys, and girls, some of whom are very valuable; also, 32 Mules, 5 Houses, 40 head of cattle, including some fine fat Oxen and Milch Cows, 35 sheep, 60 Hogs and Shoats.
125 barrels of Corn, 600 bushels wheat, Ice, Bacon, Lard etc; also, a large quantity of Hay, Cats, Fodder, Straw, and other provender; Wagons, Carts, Harness, Reapers, Threshers, Plows, Coulters, etc; in short, everything that is usually found on large and wets provided farms.

the Slaves, and all of the personal property that can be brought to the Peyton Farm, will be sold there, but such as cannot be removed there will be sold where it is; and, for that purpose, after finishing at Peyton's sale, the sale will be adjourned from Farm to Farm until the whole is disposed of.
and, upon Friday, the 17th day of April, commencing at 3½ o'clock P M, will be sold, in the following order, the real estate in and near Sidney, conveyed by the deed — to wit:

7.

After which, will be sold--

8.
The shares and interest of B W Green, being three eights of the whole, in the stock and property of the Westham Read Co.
9. Twenty shares of Stock of the Bank of Richmond.

10.
A schedule of debts due to B W Green amounting to $63,000, to be seen at the office of the trustee, and which parties interested are invited to examine before the day of sale.

div4.p: Surveys and plats of the property are now being made, and in a few days will be on exhibition at the office of the Trustee, who, as well as the auctioneers, will take pleasure in giving any information that may be desired in respect the etc, and persons wishing to purchase are invited to visit the lands, which will be shown by the overseers before the day of sale.

The parties interested under the deed are particularly requested to call at the office of the Trustee and examine its provisions, and other papers bearing upon their privileges therein, so that they may have a full understanding of their rights, and decide each for himself before the day of sale what is best for their interest.

All persons holding prior lands upon any of the property, whether by deeds of trust, titles retained judgments, or otherwise, will please furnish me before the day of sale with statements of the came, so that arrangements may be made for their speedy payment; and those holding claims against me as Trustee must present them at once.

Should the weather on either of the days above named prove unsuitable, the sale fixed for such day will be postponed until the next fair day, at the same hour, and notice of such postponement will be given through the next day's papers.

Terms of sale as prescribed by the deed.
For the real estate, ¼ cash; the balance upon a credit of 1, 2, and 3 years from the day of sale, the purchasers giving bonds or notes for the deferred payments, bearing interest from date the interest payable annually, and secured by trust deeds upon the property.
For the slaves cash; and for the personal property sums of $50 and under, cash; sums over $50, six months credit, for notes, with interest added and satisfactorily endorsed.

But the deed further provides that in lieu of the terms above stated, any holder of the paper secured thereby may purchase any of the trust property, and upon paying one quarter of their respective purchases in cash will be allowed to discharge the remaining three quarters in paper secured by the deed; but only the paper hold by the creditors who signed the deed, or the assignees of such creditors, before the sale, can be received in payment for three-fourths of any purchase.
Purchasers to pay taxes for 1863.
div4.closer:
A D Williams, Trustee.
Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers. ap 3

div4.head: P. S.
div4.p: --Cash will be received from those who may desire to anticipate the credit payments of the foregoing sales.

div3.head: By O. B. House, Auctioneer.
div3.p: Large Sale of Fresh and desirable Dry Goods and Notions, on Monday, April 13--

list.item: 12 cases Hoop Shirts, from 15 to 30 hoops

div3.p: And many other goods not enumerated.

div3.head: By E. B. Cook, Auct.
div3.p: Excellent Furniture at Auction.--On Monday, 13th inst, at 10 o'clock, I will cell at the residence, on Poplar, near 15th street, a very excellent lot of Furniture, embracing Mahogany Sofas, Chairs, Tables, Carpets, Lounge, Jenny Lind Bedstead, Hair and Shuck Mattresses, Mahogany Bureau, Bedding, etc.
--also--
A variety of Kitchens Furniture, amongst which is a first rate Cooking Stove.

div3.head: Lumber, Bricks, &c, at Auction.
div3.p: --On Monday Afternoon, 13th inst, at 3½ o'clock, I will sell, on 17th street, near the residence of Mr. Michael Purcell, a lot of Lumber, mutable for building purposes, such as Blinds, Door, Windows, Mantle Pieces, Graten, Shingles, etc, etc.
--also,--
About 6,000 Bricks.

div3.head: A very likely Rase Negro man at Auction.
div3.p: --In pursuance of an order of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond, I will sell, in front of the City Hall, on Monday next, the 13th, (that being Court day,) at 10½ o'clock A M, a very likely free negro man, named Harvey Gordon, about 20 years old, and represented as a first-rate Carpenter, said negro having been convicted by said Court of grand larceny, and ordered to be sold into absolute slavery.
div3.closer:
Thomas U Dudley,
Sergeant City of Richmond, ap 8--5t
